article.title: Multiple Disk Gaps and Rings Generated by a Single Super-Earth

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 1, what causes the formation of the multiple rings (IR, MR, OR) seen in the dust density distribution?
choices: Dust particles are trapped in low-order mean motion resonances with the planet.
Aerodynamic drag forces push dust particles toward regions of high gas pressure at the edges of planet-opened gaps.
The Rossby wave instability concentrates dust particles at the edges of the gaps.
Dust particles are trapped in pressure overdensities associated with density waves excited by the planet.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main observational difference in detectability between the gas gaps and dust rings produced by the super-Earth in Figure 2?
choices: Gas gaps are only detectable in H-band polarized intensity, while dust rings are only detectable in ALMA Band 7 observations.
Dust rings are more prominent and easier to detect than gas gaps in both H-band and ALMA observations.
Gas gaps are more extended and easier to detect than the compact dust rings in both H-band and ALMA observations.
There are no significant differences in the detectability of gas gaps and dust rings in either H-band or ALMA observations.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 3 demonstrates the effect of increasing integration time on ALMA observations of the disk.  What is the primary benefit of a longer integration time in this context?
choices: Longer integration times allow for the detection of fainter features, such as the double-gap, with higher signal-to-noise ratios.
Longer integration times are required to resolve the individual dust rings, which are not detectable with shorter integrations.
Longer integration times reduce the impact of thermal noise, making it easier to distinguish real features from artifacts.
Both A and C are correct.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 8 displays radial profiles of various disk properties for different planet masses, viscosities, and initial surface density profiles. Which of the following statements is NOT supported by the trends observed in the figure?
choices: Increasing the planet mass leads to deeper gas gaps and more prominent dust rings.
Higher disk viscosity diminishes the contrast of both gas gaps and dust rings.
The double-gap feature is only produced when the initial surface density profile follows a strict power-law.
The location and contrast of dust rings depend on the chosen global background disk profile.
